take.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
take.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Barney took us to the airport.
Would you mind taking Susie home?
When he refused to give his name, he was taken into custody.
My job has taken me all over the world.
His wife went to Australia, taking the children with her.
I have to take Steve the money tonight.
He took me to meet his parents.
take.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: used with a noun instead of using a verb to describe an action. For example, if you take a walk, you walk somewhere
take.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Would you like to take a look?
I waved, but he didn’t take any notice (=pretended not to notice). British English
Would you mind taking a photo of us together?
take.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to remove something from a place
take.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Police say money and jewellery were taken in the raid.
Take your feet off the seats.
Someone’s taken a pen from my desk.
take.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if something takes a particular amount of time, money, effort etc, that amount of time etc is needed for it to happen or succeed
take.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: How long is this going to take?
Organizing a successful street party takes a lot of energy.
It took me ages to find a present for Dad.
Catching up four goals will take some doing.
It takes courage to admit you are wrong.
Neil’s got what it takes to be a great footballer.
Repairs take time to carry out.
It took a few minutes for his eyes to adjust to the dark.
take.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to accept or choose something that is offered, suggested, or given to you
I take your point/point taken (=used to say that you accept someone’s opinion)
take.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: If you take my advice, you’ll see a doctor.
Our helpline takes 3.5 million calls (=telephone calls) a year.
Some doctors are unwilling to take new patients without a referral.
Liz found his criticisms hard to take.
I just can’t take any more (=can’t deal with a bad situation any longer).
Staff have agreed to take a 2% pay cut.
Small businesses took a hammering in the last recession.
That’s the truth – take it from me.
take somebody’s word for it/take it from somebody
He’s the kind of man who makes things happen but lets others take the credit.
It isn’t official yet, but you can take it as read that you’ve got the contract.
take.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to get hold of something in your hands
take.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Can you take this package while I get my wallet?
I just wanted to take him in my arms.
take.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to use a particular form of transport or a particular road in order to go somewhere
take.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: I took the first plane out.
take.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to study a particular subject in school or college for an examination
take.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Are you taking French next year?
take.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to do an examination or test
take.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Applicants are asked to take a written test.
take.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to be the correct or suitable size, type etc for a particular person or thing
take.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: a car that takes low sulphur fuel
What size shoe do you take?
The elevator takes a maximum of 32 people.
take.translation[0].definitions[9].note_: In this meaning, take is not used in the progressive You say
take.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to collect or gather something for a particular purpose
take.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Investigators will take samples of the wreckage to identify the cause.
The police took a statement from both witnesses.
take.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to react to someone or something or consider them in a particular way
take.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: She does not take kindly to criticism  (=reacts badly to criticism).
I take it (=I assume) you’ve heard that Rick’s resigned.
I was joking, but he took me seriously.
Ben took the news very badly.
The presence of dust clouds has been taken as evidence of recent star formation.
I’ll take that remark as a compliment.
I took her to be his daughter.
Of course I won’t tell anyone! What do you take me for? (=what sort of person do you think I am?)
take.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to have or experience a particular feeling
take.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: You should take pride in your work.
At first, he took no interest in the baby.
She stood feeling lost until an elderly man took pity on her.
Don’t take offence. Roger says things like that to everybody.
Investors can take comfort from the fact that the World Bank is underwriting the shares.
take.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: to get possession or control of something
take.translation[0].definitions[13].note: take the lead (=in a race, competition etc)
take.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: Enemy forces have taken the airport.
Youngsters need to take control of their own lives.
take.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: to swallow, breathe in, inject etc a drug or medicine
take.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: The doctor will ask whether you are taking any medication.
She took an overdose after a row with her boyfriend.
Most teenagers start taking drugs through boredom.
take.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: to make someone or something go to a higher level or position
take.translation[0].definitions[15].exam: Even if you have the talent to take you to the top, there’s no guarantee you’ll get there.
If you want to take it further, you should consult an attorney.
The latest raise takes his salary into six figures.
take.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: to measure the amount, level, rate etc of something
take.translation[0].definitions[17].defi: to make a number smaller by a particular amount
take.translation[0].definitions[17].exam: ‘Take four from nine and what do you get?’ ‘Five.’
take something away/take something (away) from something
Ten take away nine equals one.
take something away/take something (away) from something
take.translation[0].definitions[18].defi: if a shop, business etc takes a particular amount of money, it receives that amount of money from its customers
take.translation[0].definitions[19].defi: to teach a particular group of students in a school or college
take.translation[0].definitions[20].exam: Let me take your email address.
take.translation[0].definitions[21].defi: if a man takes someone, he has sex with them
take.translation[0].definitions[22].defi: if a treatment, dye, drug etc takes, it begins to work successfully
take.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
Don’t forget to take your keys.
Shall I take you home?
I took Alice a cup of tea.
bring
to take someone or something to the place where you are now
We’ve brought someone to see you!
Will you bring your photos with you when you come?
transport
to take large quantities of goods from one place to another in a plane, train, ship etc
The plane is used for transporting military equipment.
The coal was transported by rail.
deliver
to take goods, letters, newspapers etc to someone’s home or office
Unfortunately, the package was delivered to the wrong address.
fly
to take someone or something somewhere by plane
The bread is specially flown in from Paris.
to take goods from one place to another – this can be by ship, truck, plane, or train
Half the whisky is shipped to Japan and the US.
carry
to take people or goods somewhere – used especially when saying how many people or things, or what kind
The new plane can carry up to 600 passengers.
The ship was carrying a full cargo of oil.
lead
to take someone to a place by going in front of them
He led Julia through the house to his study.
Roland led the way back to the car in silence.
guide
to take someone to a place and show them the way
Emily guided him through a side gate into a large garden.
escort
to take someone to a place and protect or guard them
The prisoner was escorted into the room by two police officers.
The singer was escorted by her assistant and her bodyguard.
usher
to politely lead someone somewhere and show them where to go, especially because it is your job to do this
We were ushered into the lift by a man in uniform.
take.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an occasion when a film scene, song, action etc is recorded
take.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: We had to do six takes for this particular scene.
take.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: the amount of money earned by a shop or business in a particular period of time
take.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the amount of money earned by a business in a particular period of time
take.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: About 80% of the band’s take is from merchandise.
take.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to be willing to do something wrong or illegal in return for money
take.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: I knew he was on the take, but I never had enough evidence to prove it.
take.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to subtract one number from another number
take.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Take three from nine and what do you get?
take.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: if a business takes or takes in a particular amount of money, it earns that money from selling its goods and services
take.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: We usually take around £2000 on a Saturday.
